q: What is the hybridisation state of the carbon atom bonded to the halogen in an alkyl halide and a vinyl halide?
a: Alkyl Halide ($	ext{R}-	ext{X}$): $\mathbf{sp}^3$ hybridisation. \( \text{Vinyl Halide (}\text{CH}_2=\text{CH-X}): \mathbf{sp}^2 \text{ hybridisation.} \)

q: Order the reactivity of the following carbon-halogen bonds in a nucleophilic substitution reaction: $\text{C}-\text{F}$, $\text{C}-\text{Cl}$, $\text{C}-\text{Br}$, $\text{C}-\text{I}$
a: Reactivity increases with bond length and decreases with bond energy: \( \mathbf{\text{C}-\text{I} > \text{C}-\text{Br} > \text{C}-\text{Cl} > \text{C}-\text{F}} \) ($\text{I}^{-}$ is the best leaving group).

q: Arrange the following in increasing order of boiling points: Bromoethane, Bromoform, Chloromethane, Dibromomethane.
a: Boiling points increase with molecular mass and number of halogens: \( \mathbf{\text{Chloromethane} < \text{Bromoethane} < \text{Dibromomethane} < \text{Bromoform}} \) ($\text{CH}_3\text{Cl} < \text{CH}_3\text{CH}_2\text{Br} < \text{CH}_2\text{Br}_2 < \text{CHBr}_3$)

q: Define $\text{S}_{\text{N}}2$ reaction and state its rate determining step and stereochemical outcome.
a: It is a **bimolecular** Nucleophilic Substitution. It is a **single-step (concerted)** reaction. **Rate:** depends on both [Substrate] and [Nucleophile]. **Stereochemistry:** $\mathbf{100\%}$ **inversion of configuration** (Walden Inversion).

q: Define $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reaction and state its rate determining step and stereochemical outcome.
a: It is a **unimolecular** Nucleophilic Substitution. **Rate Determining Step:** The slow ionisation to form the $\mathbf{carbocation}$ intermediate. **Stereochemistry:** Results in a $\mathbf{racemic}$ mixture (partial or complete) due to the planar carbocation intermediate.

q: Order the relative reactivity of alkyl halides ($\text{1}^{\circ}, \text{2}^{\circ}, \text{3}^{\circ}$) towards $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ and $\text{S}_{\text{N}}2$ mechanisms.
a: $\mathbf{\text{S}_{\text{N}}1} \text{ Reactivity (based on carbocation stability): } \mathbf{3^{\circ} > 2^{\circ} > 1^{\circ} > \text{methyl}}$. \( \mathbf{\text{S}_{\text{N}}2} \text{ Reactivity (based on steric hindrance): } \mathbf{\text{methyl} > 1^{\circ} > 2^{\circ} > 3^{\circ}} \)

q: What is the preferred solvent type for $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ and $\text{S}_{\text{N}}2$ reactions?
a: $\mathbf{\text{S}_{\text{N}}1}$: Polar **Protic** solvents (e.g., $\text{H}_2\text{O}, \text{EtOH}, \text{AcOH}$) to stabilise the carbocation. \( \mathbf{\text{S}_{\text{N}}2}: \text{Polar } \mathbf{Aprotic} \text{ solvents (e.g., } \text{DMF}, \text{DMSO}, \text{Acetone}) \text{ to keep the nucleophile naked and reactive.} \)

q: Why are vinyl and aryl halides unreactive towards nucleophilic substitution under normal conditions? (Give 2 reasons)
a: 1. **Partial Double Bond Character**: Resonance stabilises the $\text{C-X}$ bond, making it stronger. 2. **Hybridisation**: The $\text{sp}^2$ C-atom is more electronegative, resulting in a shorter, stronger bond.

q: What is the product and name of the reaction when an alkyl halide reacts with $\text{KCN}$ versus $\text{AgCN}$?
a: $\mathbf{\text{KCN}}$ (ionic): Forms $\text{R-CN}$ (Alkyl **Cyanide**) - Major product, because $\text{C}$ is a better nucleophilic attacking site. \( \mathbf{\text{AgCN}} \text{ (covalent): Forms } \mathbf{\text{R-NC}} \text{ (Alkyl } \mathbf{Isocyanide}) \text{ - Major product, because } \text{Ag}-\text{CN} \text{ bond is broken and attack is through the N-atom.} \)

q: What is $\mathbf{Wurtz}$ Reaction? Write the general equation.
a: Used to prepare higher $\mathbf{alkanes}$ from alkyl halides. Two molecules of an alkyl halide react with sodium in dry ether. \( \mathbf{2\text{R}-\text{X} + 2\text{Na} \xrightarrow{\text{Dry Ether}} \text{R}-\text{R} + 2\text{NaX}} \)

q: What is $\mathbf{Fittig}$ Reaction? Write the general equation.
a: Used to prepare $\mathbf{diaryl}$ compounds. Two molecules of an aryl halide react with sodium in dry ether. \( \mathbf{2\text{Ar}-\text{X} + 2\text{Na} \xrightarrow{\text{Dry Ether}} \text{Ar}-\text{Ar} + 2\text{NaX}} \)

q: What is $\mathbf{Wurtz-Fittig}$ Reaction? Write the general equation.
a: Used to prepare $\mathbf{alkylarenes}$ (e.g., Toluene). A mixture of an alkyl halide and an aryl halide reacts with sodium in dry ether. \( \mathbf{\text{R}-\text{X} + \text{Ar}-\text{X} + 2\text{Na} \xrightarrow{\text{Dry Ether}} \text{R}-\text{Ar} + 2\text{NaX}} \)

q: What is $\mathbf{Finkelstein}$ Reaction? Write its use and conditions.
a: It is a **halogen exchange** reaction used to prepare **Alkyl Iodides** ($	ext{R}-\text{I}$). \( \mathbf{\text{R}-\text{X} + \text{NaI} \xrightarrow{\text{Acetone (dry)}} \text{R}-\text{I} + \text{NaX}} \) (The $\text{NaX}$ precipitate in acetone drives the reaction forward.)

q: What is $\mathbf{Swarts}$ Reaction? Write its use and reagent.
a: It is a **halogen exchange** reaction used to prepare **Alkyl Fluorides** ($	ext{R}-\text{F}$). \( \mathbf{\text{R}-\text{X} + \text{Metallic Fluorides (e.g., } \text{AgF}, \text{Hg}_2\text{F}_2, \text{CoF}_2, \text{SbF}_3) \to \text{R}-\text{F}} \)

q: What is $\mathbf{Sandmeyer}$ Reaction? Write the general transformation.
a: Used to replace the diazonium group ($\text{N}_2^+$) with $\text{Cl}$, $\text{Br}$, or $\text{CN}$ in an aryl ring. \( \mathbf{\text{Ar}-\text{N}_2^+ \text{Cl}^- \xrightarrow{\text{Cu}_2\text{X}_2 \text{ or } \text{CuX} \text{ (and } \text{HX)}} \text{Ar}-\text{X}} \text{ (where } \text{X} = \text{Cl}, \text{Br}, \text{CN})} \)

q: How does the $\mathbf{Gatterman}$ Reaction differ from the $\mathbf{Sandmeyer}$ Reaction for preparing aryl halides?
a: Both reactions are used to convert the diazonium salt to an aryl halide. $\mathbf{\text{Gatterman}}$ uses **Copper powder** (e.g., $\text{Cu}/\text{HCl}$) instead of $\text{Cu}(\text{I})$ salts (e.g., $\text{Cu}_2\text{Cl}_2$) used in $\mathbf{\text{Sandmeyer}}$. Sandmeyer usually gives better yields.

q: State $\mathbf{Saytzeff's}$ Rule for elimination reactions ($	ext{E}1/	ext{E}2$).
a: In a dehydrohalogenation reaction, the preferred product is the $\mathbf{most}$ **highly substituted alkene** (i.e., the alkene that has the greater number of alkyl groups attached to the double-bonded carbon atoms).

q: Why is the $\text{C-X}$ bond in haloarenes shorter and stronger than in haloalkanes?
a: In haloarenes, the carbon atom is $\mathbf{sp}^2$ hybridised. $\text{An } \text{sp}^2 \text{ carbon is more electronegative than an } \mathbf{sp}^3 \text{ carbon (as in haloalkanes)}$, resulting in a shorter and stronger $\text{C}-\text{X}$ bond due to better orbital overlap.

q: Explain the directing effect of the halogen group in electrophilic substitution reactions on haloarenes.
a: Halogens are $\mathbf{Ortho/Para-directing}$ (due to resonance, which increases electron density at $o-$ and $p-$ positions) but $\mathbf{Deactivating}$ (due to the strong electron-withdrawing inductive effect, which reduces overall electron density in the ring).

q: Preparation Method: Conversion of Alcohol to Alkyl Halide (Darzen's Method)
a: The best method for preparing $\text{R}-\text{Cl}$ is by reacting the alcohol with $\mathbf{\text{Thionyl Chloride } (\text{SOCl}_2)}$ in the presence of pyridine. \( \mathbf{\text{R}-\text{OH} + \text{SOCl}_2 \xrightarrow{\text{Pyridine}} \text{R}-\text{Cl} + \text{SO}_2\text{(g)} + \text{HCl(g)}} \) The gaseous by-products make purification easy.

q: Preparation Method: Addition of Hydrogen Halides to Alkenes (Markovnikov's Rule)
a: The negative part of the unsymmetrical reagent ($\text{H}-\text{X}$) adds to the carbon atom of the double bond that has the **least number of hydrogen atoms** (forms the more stable carbocation intermediate). Peroxide effect is the exception for $\text{HBr}$.

q: Ambident Nucleophile: Products from $\text{KNO}_2$ vs $\text{AgNO}_2$
a: $\mathbf{\text{KNO}_2}$ (ionic): Forms $\text{R}-\text{O}-\text{N}=\text{O}$ (Alkyl **Nitrite**) - attack is via the O-atom. \( \mathbf{\text{AgNO}_2} \text{ (covalent): Forms } \mathbf{\text{R}-\text{NO}_2} \text{ (Nitroalkane)} \text{ - attack is via the N-atom.} \)

q: What is a 'Racemic Mixture' and what causes its formation in $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ reactions?
a: A Racemic Mixture contains **equal amounts** of the two enantiomers ($\text{D}$ and $\text{L}$ forms). It is **optically inactive** (rotation is cancelled out). It forms because the planar carbocation intermediate in $\text{S}_{\text{N}}1$ can be attacked from **either side** with equal probability.

q: Definition: Enantiomers and Chiral Carbon
a: **Enantiomers** are non-superimposable mirror images of each other. A **Chiral Carbon** is a carbon atom bonded to $\mathbf{four}$ **different groups**.

q: Environmental Impact: What is $\text{DDT}$ and what is its major problem?
a: $\mathbf{\text{DDT}}$ (Dichloro-diphenyl-trichloroethane) is a powerful, cheap insecticide. Its major problem is that it is **non-biodegradable** and accumulates in the food chain (bio-magnification), causing toxicity, especially in fish and birds.
